row.entry: These rules contain comprehensive powers to give directions directed towards achieving the “just, quick and cheap disposal of the proceedings”. They complement several provisions of the CP Act, including ss 14–16 and ss 61–63 , which also confer significant procedural discretions.
This Part applies to all courts in CPA Sch 1: see r 1.5 and Sch 1 . Rules 2.1 and 2.2 apply to the criminal proceedings in the Third Schedule to the Supreme Court Act: see SCR Pt 75 r 3 .

The rules substantially reproduce the wording of the former SCR rr 26.1–26.3. General directions powers, expressed in similar terms to the present r 1.1, were contained in the previous provisions such as SCA s 76A and DCA s 68A.
Directions convenient for “just, quick and cheap disposal of the proceedings” ‥ [2.1.5]
Scope of the directions power — examples ‥ [2.1.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 2.1] r 2.1 Directions and orders (cf SCR Part 26, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Directions and orders (cf SCR Part 26, rule 1)

p.text: The court may, at any time and from time to time, give such directions and make such orders for the conduct of any proceedings as appear convenient (whether or not inconsistent with these rules or any other rules of court) for the just, quick and cheap disposal of the proceedings.

See also the guiding principles in relation to the conduct of court proceedings (set out in Division 1 of Part 6 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005) and the general powers of the court to give directions (set out in Division 2 of that Part).

level.toc-caption: [2.1.5] Directions convenient for “just, quick and cheap disposal of the proceedings”

p.text: Legislation cited in [2.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56–58, ss 61–63.

heading.title: Directions convenient for “just, quick and cheap disposal of the proceedings”

p.text: The discretion conferred by the rule is exercisable for the purpose of ensuring the real issues in dispute are determined as efficiently as the circumstances of each particular case admits. This rule complements the provisions contained in CPA ss 56–58 and ss 61–63 . The principal intention of those various provisions is to require early and proper consideration of the real issues in proceedings, and the manner in which evidence should be presented, for the purpose of reducing the length and cost of the proceedings. The directions power allows the court to adopt special procedures for the purpose of attempting to reduce the time and expense of trials, especially where hearings are potentially long and complex, and where this can be done consistently with the requirements of justice: WEA Records Ltd v Visions Channel 4 Ltd [1983] 2 All ER 589; [1983] 1 WLR 721 at 722 ; Connelly v DPP [1964] AC 1254 at 1317; [1964] 2 WLR 1145 ; Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd v Hutcheson (No 3) (1983) 8 ACLR 526 at 537 . The court’s powers are general and do not depend upon the particular proceedings being in one of the court’s special lists: Baerlein v Chartered Merchant Bank [1895] 2 Ch 488 at 491 ; Lazarus v Deutsche Lufthansa AG (1985) 1 NSWLR 188; Giorgi v European Asian Bank AG (NSWSC, McLelland J, Eq, 4644/85, 3 March 1986, unreported, BC8601212). In some cases, the exercise of the discretion may result in the imposition of additional procedural steps (Lazarus , above, verification of particulars); in others it may mean dispensing with routine steps that are unnecessary, having regard to the essential issues in dispute. While the discretion conferred by the rule is wide, it is to be exercised with some degree of circumspection. The court should not unnecessarily restrict the flexibility of proceedings by pre-trial directions. Ordinarily it will be appropriate for the court to have regard to the wishes of the parties and it has been said that the court ought not unduly interfere with the manner in which a party proposes to prove its case unless there is a tendency for the proposed course of action to cause prejudice, embarrassment or unnecessary expense and delay: John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Foord (1988) 12 NSWLR 706 at 712 ; Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 at 346 .

level.toc-caption: [2.1.10] Scope of the directions power — examples

p.text: Legislation cited in [2.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 s 207.

heading.title: Scope of the directions power — examples

p.text: The scope of the directions power conferred by the general terms of the present rule is educated by the more explicit, but merely inclusive, terms of CPA ss 61 , 62 and 63 . The generality of the power and the impressionistic nature of the desiderata expressed as governing its principled exercise (ie, “just, quick and cheap”) permit a wide range of orders to be made. On the other hand, the characterisation of the power as being one to give directions in relation to the conduct of the proceedings, together with the limitations expressed in CPA ss 57(1)(a) , 58(2)(b)(vi) and 62(4) , suggest that the power cannot be used to alter, or circumvent, substantive rights: Griffin v Sogelease Australia Ltd (2003) 57 NSWLR 257; [2003] NSWCA 158; BC200303257 (no power to direct discovery or production of documents by a person entitled to claim privilege against incrimination). Neither should the power be exercised on terms that impose conditions not properly relevant to the immediate matter in issue. Thus on an application for an extension of time to comply with a particular order it is impermissible to impose a condition unrelated to the circumstances involved in the extension application itself: Victoria v Davies (2003) 6 VR 245 at 259; [2003] VSCA 65; BC200302798 (no power, subject to the specific provision in CPA s 61(3) , to require waiver of privilege nor to preclude the tender of admissible evidence). Subject to these broad limitations the directions power is extensive. Its potential scope is illustrated by, though neither defined by nor confined to, the following examples (in addition to those set out in CPA s 62 ):

an order requiring a party to obtain originals or copies of documents which, though identified in its list of discovered documents, were no longer in the party’s possession: Roach v Page (t/as Freehill Hollingdale and Page) (NSWSC, McLaughlin M, No 4266/95, 22 April 1998, unreported, BC9802253).
directions requiring a party to make an application for the production of documents under FOI legislation: Schipp v Cameron (1997) 38 ATR 1; BC9707032 ; see further [21.3.30] .

directions requiring a party to authorise disclosure of documents to which a statutory prohibition against disclosure (such as the prohibition under s 207 of the Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 (Cth)) would otherwise apply: Wray v Wray [2007] NSWSC 164; BC200701272 per Gzell J ( s 207 of the SS(A)T Act order made against Centrelink on application of plaintiff); Merkuloff v Yalisheff [2003] NSWSC 1183; BC200307581 , Young CJ in Eq (order made on application by a defendant); Attard v Hore [2002] QSC 437; BC200208495 , Dutney J (order made on application by a defendant).

directions restraining a party form sending harassing and offensive written communications to officers and legal representatives of the other party: McGuirk v University of New South Wales [2010] NSWCA 104; BC201003694
Legislation cited in [2.1.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 14, s 16.

CPA s 14 confers a statutory power to dispense with the requirements of the rules whenever the court is satisfied it is appropriate to do so in the particular circumstances. CPA s 16 permits courts to give directions where no specific provision appears in the rules. The annotations to both sections are relevant to the power conferred by the present rule.
Legislation cited in [2.1.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, s 58, s 61(2).

heading.title: Power to dismiss or strike out

p.text: The power to give directions necessarily carries with it a power to sanction non-compliance. That power derives partly from the incidental power to control and supervise the conduct of proceedings, and partly from the terms of CPA s 61(2) . The latter provision includes explicit powers to strike out claims, defences, any other documents and power to strike out evidence. Where a party has failed to comply with interlocutory directions in relation to the filing of witness statements or affidavits, the power would include refusing reliance on the additional material and refusal of any application for an adjournment by the defaulting party: State Pollution Control Commission v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 487; 75 LGERA 327; BC9203134 ; Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625 at 636; 67 ALJR 841; BC9303602 per Toohey and Gaudron JJ; Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379; 104 ALR 165 ; Multigroup Distribution Services Pty Ltd v TNT Australia Pty Ltd [2001] FCA 1144; BC200104838 (late service of additional witness statements raising extensive new factual material and jeopardising commencement of long complex litigation); GSA Industries Pty Ltd v NT Gas Ltd (1990) 24 NSWLR 710 .

heading.title: Balancing interests in the dictates of justice

p.text: The overriding considerations in the exercise of the power to sanction default are the “just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues” (see CPA s 56 ) and the “dictates of justice” — as defined in CPA s 58 — in the circumstances of the particular case: Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 ; Brown v Petranker (1991) 22 NSWLR 717; (1991) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-088 . This widely-stated purposive discretion can produce tension, and differing views, about the appropriateness of its exercise where doing so would impede or prevent fair and just determination of the real merits of the disputed issues. There is no doubt that, in some circumstances, a party who fails to comply with directions may properly be left to bear the consequences of the default, including dismissal of the proceedings: Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 (repeated failure to file amended particulars); Bibah Formwork Pty Ltd v Radray Constructions Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 599; BC200304043 (persistent non-compliance with Magistrate’s directions — claim dismissed). However, proper application of the “overriding purpose” and “dictates of justice” criteria require consideration of the degree of injustice that would be inflicted on the respective parties by the proposed decision. This will inevitably involve consideration of the apparent materiality of the matter to the substance of the issues in the proceedings, the nature, reasons for and the extent of the default and the relative appropriateness of particular ameliorative sanctions and directions: see Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 at [36]–[47] and [s 58.35] . (And in this respect the considerations relevant to the exercise of the sanction power are similar to those that inform the exercise of the discretionary power to dismiss a claim or defence for lack of “due despatch”: see [12.7.5] .)

heading.title: Desirability of determination of the merits of proceedings

p.text: The possibility that the defaulting party may be deprived of a determination of the merits of their claim or defence is a weighty, and often determinative, consideration. It is particularly likely to be determinative where the default has occurred at an early stage, or where there are material explanatory circumstances. The consistent application of these two propositions is illustrated in numerous decisions — of which the following are merely illustrative examples:
Erhard v Bhatia [2002] NSWCA 388; BC200207243 (significant medical negligence claim dismissed for non-compliance — lack of prejudice to defendant — dismissal overturned on appeal);
Tremeer v City of Stirling [2002] WASCA 281; BC200206179 at [33] (dilatory plaintiff disadvantaged by service of responsive reports raising unanticipated issues –– adjournment granted on appeal);

Kane v Wyllie [2006] NSWSC 710; BC200605394 (4 month period of non-compliance with Registrar’s directions — party’s solicitor suffering medical problems — self-executing order that proceedings would be dismissed if further non-compliance);

Reliance Financial Services Pty Ltd v Criniti [2006] NSWSC 715; BC200605442 (multiple instances of non-compliance with Registrar’s orders — change of solicitors — difficulties in obtaining client file from former solicitors and difficulties in obtaining instructions from former director now in prison — proceedings not dismissed);

Chandra v Perpetual Trustess Victoria Ltd (No 2) [2006] NSWSC 1344; BC200610124 (failure to comply with directions on three occasions, default remedied before interlocutory process completed — proceedings not significantly delayed — proceedings not dismissed).

heading.title: Alternative orders to dismissal or strike out

p.text: The appropriate sanction for non-compliance may sometimes be further directions which impose self-executing consequences for non-compliance: Phornpisutikul v Mileto [2006] NSWSC 57; BC200600626 at [15]–[22] (repeated failure to comply with directions over more than a year — self-executing order that proceedings be dismissed unless all evidence-in-chief and a solicitor’s certificate of compliance be filed before a specified date). In other circumstances the appropriate sanction may lie in depriving a party of an incidental advantage to which it would otherwise have been entitled in the proceedings: Hopeshore Pty Ltd v Melroad Equipment Pty Ltd (2004) 212 ALR 66; 51 ACSR 259; [2004] FCA 1445; BC200407452 (dilatory applicant refused security for costs).
Legislation cited in [2.1.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 86.
CPA s 86 permits the court to impose terms on the making of any order or direction.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 2.2] r 2.2 Appointment for hearing (cf SCR Part 26, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Appointment for hearing (cf SCR Part 26, rule 2)

p.text: The court may, at any time and from time to time, of its own motion, appoint a date for a hearing at which it may give or make the directions or orders referred to in UCPR r 2.1 .

The Supreme Court has established a telephone conference call facility used principally for common law directions hearings before the Registrar. Consent matters and matters where the parties or their legal representatives are located outside the Sydney CBD are suitable for telephone directions hearings. A telephone hearing can proceed if one or more parties chose to appear in person. Adjournments, directions and allocation of hearing dates may be obtained by telephone callover. Telephone directions hearings take place every Tuesday morning and at other times by special arrangement. Parties who wish to have their matter entered into, or removed from, the telephone directions list should apply (by fax or letter) to the Common Law Case Management Registrar. The application must:
be received at least three working days prior to the scheduled directions hearing or conference;
briefly outline the reasons for the application; and
indicate whether or not the application is by consent.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 2.3] r 2.3 Case management by the court (cf SCR Part 26, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Case management by the court (cf SCR Part 26, rule 3)

p.text: Without limiting the generality of rule 2.1 , directions and orders may relate to any of the following:
the filing of pleadings,
the defining of issues, including requiring the parties, or their legal practitioners, to exchange memoranda in order to clarify questions,
the provision of any essential particulars,
the filing of "Scott Schedules" referred to in rule 15.2 ,
the making of admissions,
the filing of lists of documents, either generally or with respect to specific matters,
the delivery or exchange of experts’ reports and the holding of conferences of experts,
the provision of copies of documents, including their provision in electronic form,
the administration and answering of interrogatories, either generally or with respect to specific matters,
the service and filing of affidavits, witness statements or other documents to be relied on,
the giving of evidence at any hearing, including whether evidence of witnesses in chief must be given orally, or by affidavit or witness statement, or both,
the use of telephone or video conference facilities, video tapes, film projection, computer and other equipment and technology,
the provision of evidence in support of an application for an adjournment or amendment,
a timetable with respect to any matters to be dealt with, including a timetable for the conduct of any hearing,
the filing of written submissions.

level.toc-caption: [2.3.5] Substantive provisions of the Civil Procedure Act

p.text: Legislation cited in [2.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 26 r 3.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 31, r 29.5, 29.6.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 61, 62.

heading.title: Substantive provisions of the Civil Procedure Act

p.text: The present rule substantially reproduces the former SCR Pt 26 r 3 and complements the powers conferred by UCPR r 29.5 and CPA ss 61 – 62 . The latter section contains specific power to give various directions relating to the conduct of the hearing of proceedings. The notes to UCPR rr 29.5 and 29.6 deal generally with procedural matters relevant to the conduct of hearings and the kind of directions that may be made in particular cases. In addition, a number of specific provisions regulating the ordinary conduct of hearings are contained in UCPR Pt 31 .
Legislation cited in [2.3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Many of the kinds of directions contemplated by the present rule are the subject of detailed provisions in other parts of the rules — for example:

Under UCPR r 2.3(h) and (l) the court may give directions relating to the use of technology in the conduct of proceedings. Practice Note SC Gen 7 applies to directions and related procedures in connection with proceedings in the Supreme Court. Such directions may be particularly appropriate to facilitate the exchange of large numbers of documents.
